q: to Be Rude, But..." in which he laid down five important principles that actors can use when auditioning. 1. Don't grovel when you come in. Simon Cowell writes I look upon it[ groveling] as a sign of desperation. So many times people come in and they come up with this terrible dialogue about how much they like me or Randy or Paula. It's demeaning, and there's no point to it. We're not looking for a nice person; we're looking for somebody who's confident and assured, but talented above all. Trust me-- most stars aren't nice. 2. Believe in yourself the second you leave the house. "Self-possession isn't something you can turn on seconds before you walk into the audition room. People like Ruben or Kelly

Apple directors Al Gore and Bill Campbell remain advisers to Google. Arthur D. Levinson has been a key part of Google's success these past five years, offering unvarnished advice and vital counsel on every big issue and opportunity Google has faced, Eric Schmidt said in a release. The competition between Apple and Google signals an increasingly tense relationship for the long-time allies. CBS has announced. Mitt Romney , who was a 2008 Republican presidential candidate, is to appear on the program Tuesday. He is promoting the publication of the paperback version of his book, No Apology: Believe in America. This will be Mitt Romney 's second visit to the CBS broadcast. He previously sat down for an interview with David Letterman on the "Late Show" last March 2, the network noted. Also

Mike Pence will not run for president in 2012. AP Photo/Carlos Osorio Indiana Rep. Mike Pence will not run for president but has left the door open to running for governor of the Hoosier State in 2012. In the choice between seeking national office and serving Indiana in some capacity, we choose Indiana, Mike Pence said in a Mike Pence has been publicly mulling whether to run for the open governor's office or for president for several months. Acerbic British music judge and entrepreneur Simon Cowell said on Monday that the winner of the first U.S. version of the television singing competition, "The X Factor, will receive a$ 5 million record deal.
